title.narrative: Publication and Dissemination of Mass Violence Study
Publication et diffusion d'une étude sur la violence de masse

description.narrative: This Research Support Project (RSP) is being developed to assist Centre for Equity Studies (CES) to publish and disseminate the study "Accountability for Mass Violence: Examining the State's record". The Study formed a significant effort, almost first of its kind, supported by the IDRC. By painstaking piecing together of official but unshared information collected through hundreds of Right to Information (RTI) applications, this research builds a public record for four cases of mass violence -1983 Nellie, Assam; 1984 Anti-Sikh violence in Delhi; 1989 Bhagalpur and 2002 Gujarat - on three specific dimensions of state accountability namely, access to criminal justice, accountability of public officials and compensation and rehabilitation. The public record so formed, successfully holds up the mirror to governments and public authorities and institutions and evaluate the accountability and impunity of public officials after episodes of mass violence. This comparative study is significant as it uses RTI in human rights area and points to some other critical elements of the RTI, its crucial relevance to contemporary governance debates and around the notion of citizens' right to truth and justice. The study report is a crucial document and needs to be printed and disseminated widely so that it can contribute to ongoing discussions on justice and accountability.
